question: Where is the TAZ (G4.5) is located in humans?
ideal_answer: TAZ gene (G4.5) is located on Xq28 in humans.

snippets.text: Tafazzin (EC 2.3.1.23) is a Phospholipid Transacylase involved in Cardiolipin remodeling on mitochondrial membrane and coded by TAZ gene (Cytogenetic Location: Xq28) in human.

Barth syndrome is an X-linked cardiomyopathy with neutropenia and 3-methylglutaconic aciduria. Recently, mutations in the G4.5 gene, located in Xq28, have been described in four probands with Barth syndrome.
The disorder is caused by mutations in the tafazzin (TAZ/G4.5) gene located on Xq28.
Disabling mutations or deletions of the tafazzin (TAZ) gene, located at Xq28, cause the disorder by reducing remodeling of cardiolipin, a principal phospholipid of the inner mitochondrial membrane
The tafazzin gene (TAZ) is located at Xq28 and encodes a protein involved in the transacylation of cardiolipin, an essential mitochondrial phospholipid
The disorder is caused by mutations in the tafazzin (TAZ/G4.5) gene located on Xq28
The disorder is caused by mutations in the tafazzin (TAZ/G4.5) gene located on Xq28.
Recently, mutations in the G4.5 gene, located in Xq28, have been described in four probands with Barth syndrome.
